As I have said, in the long run we will get no thanks for whatever we do.

There is a political problem, too. As one honorable member said, there are no political partiies in the Territory now that we know of. I think there will be in the future. We can be certain that the Communist Party is thinking about this Territory now, if it has not been thinking about it for some time. That is something that we must bear in mind. The Communists are moving down from the north now and they may think they can move into this place. Unless we give the right guidance to the people in this legislature, we shall store up a lot of trouble for ourselves in the future.

We want a society in this place that is independent and self-sufficient, and that could be brought about. New Guinea is not a rich country but, as the honorable member for East Sydney has said, it is not a poor country. It is capable of development but it will require a lot of money to be spent on it. Where that money will come from, I do not know, but Australia will have to find a large proportion. The tragedy is that we spend more in that part of the world than in north Queensland. However, I suppose it would be useless for me to complain about that because it would not get me anywhere.

As I have said, I think it is important, not only that we should lead the indigenous people to self-government, but also that the white people who live and work there with their families should have some incentive to stay. I do not think that at the moment they are very happy about what is happening. This is a big problem which is worthy of great consideration, and I hope the Government will give it that consideration.

talk.start.para: -The answer to the honorable member's questions is as follows: - 1 to 4. The question of the issue of a separate medal for Australian and New Zealand troops who fought at Gallipoli was first proposed at the time of the First World War, but the proposal was not adopted, as it was felt to be unfair to members of the forces of other countries who had fought there. In addition, it was thought inappropriate to have a special Gallipoli Star, whilst not giving similar recognition to troops in other combat areas. The same question has been raised on many occasions since, and the same view has been taken by successive Australian governments. The New Zealand Government is not in favour of the matter being re-opened at this stage. My Government's decision on the matter last year was in line with these earlier decisions. The Government is not unmindful of the significance for Australia of the Gallipoli Campaigns, nor of the part played by Australian and New Zealand ex-servicemen in them. Indeed, the place of these events in Australian history is permanent, and will not be affected by the actions of any government. Nevertheless, the Government considers that the awarding of a commemorative medal for the Gallipoli campaign is a matter on which Australia should not take any independent action and that, in any case, the lapse of time has been so great, particularly with the Second World War intervening, that it would be inappropriate to re-open the matter now.

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: In view of the proposal by Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett-A.N.A. to introduce Boeing jet airliners into service on their internal capital city air routes in the near future, will the Minister take steps to have the war-time igloos now serving as passenger terminal installations at Eagle Farm Airport, Brisbane, demolished and erect in their place a modern jet air terminal comparable with those in Sydney and Melbourne in keeping with the modern jet age and with the advancement and' development of a city as beautiful and with as much potential as Brisbane?
Would the provision of a modern up to date air terminal at Eagle Farm, Brisbane, also be of great assistance in developing the tourist trade in Queensland generally?

Will the Minister also take steps to have Eagle Farm Airport, Brisbane, gazetted as either a principal entry or exit port for overseas airliners entering or leaving Australia thus simplifying air travel arrangements for overseas tourists visiting Australia and abolishing the necessity for blackflights to be made by tourists wishing to visit the capital cities of Australia?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following information: -

item.para: The provision of new passenger accommodation at Brisbane airport involves not only new buildings but the development of a new building area generally. The works will include aprons and their associated taxiways and the whole project would run into some millions of pounds. There is, of necessity, only a certain amount of money which can be used each year for development generally and only a certain amount' of this can be spent on airports. While recognizing that improved passenger facilities at Brisbane are desirable, it is not thought that the need for them is as great as the need for the runway extensions at Sydney, a new airport to serve Melbourne and many other projects, both large and small, throughout Australia. In this regard I would point out that more than £2,000,000 has already been spent in the development at Brisbane Airport, and a runway almost 8,000 feet in length, capable of taking the large jet aircraft which are now in operation, and in equipping it with airport lighting and an instrument landing system. This was the second such runway to be developed in Australia and Brisbane, has for some years, been able to handle the large jet aircraft very satisfactorily. The improvement of passenger facilities at Brisbane, must, however, take its proper place in the priority of other works to be done throughout Australia. The present buildings being used as passenger terminals at Brisbane will be kept in good and satsfactory condition until the new building area can be developed.

While a modern air terminal at Brisbane airport would undoubtedly be a benefit for tourists in Queensland, it is not thought that it would be of any great assistance in the actual development of the tourist trade. This development would be related rather to the many attractions which the State has to offer in its various places, than to such things as the terminal buildings of an airport.

I am not quite sure what is meant in the question by " A principal entry or exit port ". Brisbane Airport is already designated as an international airport with a direct entry from New Zealand. It also handles services to and from Europe which are virtually a direct entry into Australia, since the only other airport between them and overseas territories is Darwin, which is largely in the nature of a technical refuelling stop.

talk.start.para: d asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that the present passenger lounge at the Kalgoorlie airport is most unsuitable to meet the weather conditions of the area and that, as a result, passengers prefer to stand outside rather than enter the building?
If so, will he arrange for early reconstruction or replacement of the lounge room in such a way as to provide comfortable conditions for the people using the airways?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following information: -

item.para: It is not considered that the present passenger lounge at Kalgoorlie airport is most unsuitable to meet the weather conditions which prevail there. It consists of an enclosed area and also quite a large verandah which provide satisfactory shelter and normal airline office and other accommodation.

Passenger traffic through Kalgoorlie airport has been declining for some years and now stands at about 300 passengers per month. Under such circumstances it would be very difficult to justify any replacement in the existing building which is catering satisfactorily for the existing traffic. Matters such as this are kept continually under review and you may be sure that if traffic at Kalgoorlie does rise to a stage where additional accommodation is needed to cater for it satisfactorily, full consideration will be given to providing this accommodation.

talk.start.para: y asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

talk.start.para: son asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Are existing quarantine regulations considered to be capable of preventing the spread of such diseases as rabies and foot and mouth disease from Indonesia to Papua, New Guinea and the Australian mainland?
Are sufficientqualified staff available in Papua and New Guinea and Australia to handle any outbreak of an imported disease?

Does the -Department of Health keep its. own personnel. State Health Department personnel and the veterinary profession informed of the world animal health situation in order that imported diseases might be quickly recognized?

Have there been any recent examples where the quarantine provisions of Australia, Papua and New Guinea have been ineffective in preventing the spread of animal diseases from Asian countries to Australia?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Animal quarantine legislation of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea is adequate and well implemented at sea ports and air ports. In some inland areas along the border there are problems arising from difficult terrain. As far as Australia itself is concerned Indonesia and the Territory of Papua and New Guinea are regarded, under animal quarantine legislation and policy, as overseas countries and countries of potential animal disease risk. Legislation is adequate to deal with this risk.

The honorable member will be aware that there is a shortage of veterinarians in many countries of the world. This shortage is evident in Australia. With regard to the Territory of Papua and New Guinea, its veterinary staff and ancillary lay staff, in co-operation with other instrumentalities of the Administration, is adequate to deal "with the present situation. However, in the event of the introduction of a serious contagious disease of animals, assistance from Australia might be required. In Australia itself the Animal Quarantine Service is well staffed by veterinarians and ancillary lay staff. I understand that there are vacancies in most State departments of agriculture for field veterinary officers.

Information on the world animal disease position is received regularly by the Department of Health from the International Veterinary Bureau and from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. This information is distributed to all Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) who are principal veterinary officers of the State departments of agriculture and in the case of the Northern Territory to the Director of Animal Industry of the Northern Territory Administration. The publication " Exotic Infectious Diseases of Animals, their Recognition and Control ", originally issued in 1950 by my department to all veterinarians in Australia, was amplified and re-issued in 1960. 1 am pleased to inform the honorable member that this extremely valuable document is again in the course of extensive revision, after which it will be distributed to all members of the veterinary profession in Australia. 4. No.
